Typography.StandardSwashes="0" Typography.ContextualSwashes="0" Typography.StylisticAlternates="0"><Paragraph><Run FontWeight="Bold" FontSize="14.25">Purpose:</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run> This network demonstrates the SpeechIn and SpeechOut modules which handle speech using the native speech engine. When words are detected, neurons fire in the SpeechIn module which are synapsed to corresponding neurons in the SpeechOut which will repeat the words it received.</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run FontWeight="Bold" FontSize="14.25">Things to try:</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run> First: fire neurons in the SpeechOut module and listen for spoken words to verify that speech synthesis is working.</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run> Make sure your computer microphone is enabled and say "Computer, 1,2,3". The 1,2,3 neurons should fire in order and the computer should repeat the phrase 1,2,3. "Computer" is the "wake" word which helps make the speech-recognition be more accurate by ignoring random noise.</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run FontWeight="Bold" FontSize="14.25">Current state of development:</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run> This is a diagnostic which is generally complete. Subsequent iterations of bigger networks use the SpeakPhonemes Module.</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run> This network uses the speech engine inherent on your computer, so it includes all the limitations and inaccuracies of the underlying engine.</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run FontWeight="Bold" FontSize="14.25">Notes:</Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run></Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run></Run></Paragraph><Paragraph><Run></Run></Paragraph></Section>
